meaning_mnemonic:
This radical means <radical>orders</radical>, because it looks like Napoleon with his big bicorne hat, giving orders. You move, or his orders move you.

See how his body looks like the stamp radical (卩)? If it helps, you can think of Napoleon's written orders as bearing his stamp of approval. All official orders need the stamp of that guy under the big hat, you know?

This radical is the same as the kanji you learned earlier, but the meaning is a little different. It's not just for saying things humbly, it's for being <radical>humble</radical> in general. When you see this radical, think about being humble.

You can kinda see this as someone with their hands pressed together in front of their body, in a very humble posture. Maybe a humble Buddhist monk wearing some big robes? Imagine him all humble there, head bowed, hands pressed together.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>older brother</radical>.

In case you need a refresher, here's the mnemonic again: Who's someone who's just a mouth with legs? That's your know-it-all older brother, who won't shut up about anything.

Remember the stairs (乃) radical? This is a lot like that, but it has another stroke to motorize it. The extra bit makes the stairs move by themselves — that's why this is an <radical>escalator</radical>!

This is a ceremony radical with a slide radical. Why would a ceremony need a slide? For <radical>drunkard</radical>s, of course! People love to drink at ceremonies, and when they've had too much, those drunkards like to go down slides. If your ceremony has a slide, the drunkards will be happy.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>skin</radical>.

Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: You go down a slide made of branches and your skin scrapes right off — ouch! Lucky for you, it was just your old outer layer of skin, and now you've got a fresh shiny layer. Yay for exfoliation! You're not sure what to do with this big, floppy layer of old skin, though…

Imagine a <radical>root</radical> vegetable, like a turnip or something. See the twisted bulb at the top, with long, stringy root tendrils dangling under it? That's why this is the root radical.

Alternatively, focus on the components: sun and kick. When the sun is out, you're outside kicking things around. But be careful — kick a root, and you might trip over it!

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>sound</radical>. You can even see someone standing at a kind of square table here. It's a DJ at the turntables! Imagine them spinning records and scratching out all kinds of cool sounds.

You could also remember this with the kanji mnemonic we gave you. Here's the gist of it: If you stand on the sun, you'll hear a very loud sizzling sound.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>few</radical>.

Here's a mnemonic refresher, just in case: You have a small slide. The thing about small slides is that <kanji>few</kanji> people can use them. Not everyone can fit their bum in a small slide — only a few small ones can make it down. That's why this means "few"!

This the radical for <radical>simple</radical>. Why? Because it looks like a simple little stick figure drawing! Just a big head on top with a few hairs, and a stick figure body. What could be more simple?
You have the radical twenty and the kanji one. Put those together and you get 21. What's another name for 21? That's <radical>blackjack</radical>.

There's a lid on top of something you're trying to keep private. It's your <radical>trash</radical>. You wouldn't want people going through your private trash, which is why we put lids on our trash cans. It's also illegal to look through someone's trash, so make sure you never do that.

This is the radical for <radical>bear</radical>, because it looks like the letter B — B for bear! You know this one is "bear" and not "building" because it's all boxy, like a stocky, chunky bear who's all fat and ready to hibernate.
